I would regret not giving it a shot. I've done things that I believe are genuinely impressive for graduates in the field, and am very obviously passionate about classical computing culture, etc. MIT seems to be one of the only places that cares about selecting for that kind of thing anymore, all the other institutions trip over themselves to LARP as Harvard.

There are two rough kinds of universities in my mind --the first is the hacker-type (e.g. MIT, Caltech), where if the institution was disbanded tomorrow, and degrees were no longer offered, everyone would probably still show up to class, just because they're in it for the love of the game.

The other sort selects for a campus population that is more likely to become the upper-class of the world -- the Parkland shooting kid didn't get into Harvard out of some kind of social obligation, it's because almost dying in a domestic terrorist event and leveraging it to start a national politisperg movement is exactly the kind of thing Harvard is looking for. This is why inexplicably having 1337 volunteer hours and starting a non-profit for paraplegic black trans hookers is meta for uni admissions these days, instead of actually giving a shit about the major you're applying for.

i would assume your parents are paying and that they would be happy to pay for MIT if you get in. if they are not paying, you almost certainly don't want to go into debt, but it depends on your goals. if it's just getting a job at some place after your degree, any decent college is sufficient provided you apply for internships, leetcode, and do other job-related things early. T50 is enough for getting into big tech or even jane street. if you want to be an academiacuck/really want to do research with professors then going to a school with a better brand name will definitely help in terms of getting good research opportunities and getting into a good grad school. if you just care about intellectual development in general, debt is not worth it in the age of the internet. you can contribute to whatever open source projects you want, study whatever you want, talk to people over the internet. i say this with a lot of familiarity with undergraduate CS curriculum at the tippy top colleges.

posts.com: I keep reading of all the advantages of micro-algae over traditional food plants. Better kcal and nutrient production per square meter or kWh of light, etc. If this is all true, why is algae powder so expensive? And why are algae only consumed in extremely small quantities, i.e. a few grams? Why is there no algae main dish?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15051199
One reason is that microalgae are not as palatable as many other foods, so they are not commonly used as a main dish. Additionally, the production of microalgae on a large scale can be challenging and expensive, which makes algae-based products relatively expensive. Finally, microalgae are not a particularly well-known source of food, so there is not as much demand for them as there is for other, more traditional foods.

>>14938339
>Is there a definitive physics text for undergraduate calculus based physics 1 and 2?
No, they're all more or less the same. The standard in my state when I did my undergrad was Halliday, Resnik, and Krane. The standard at the school I'm teaching at is Serway. For better or worse every intro physics sequence follows basically the same pattern: Physics I - mechanics and thermo, Physics II - E&M and modern. And all the books go through basically the same structure and routine for introducing topics:
You start with kinematics because it's the basis for all the vector and calculus language you're going to be using for describing motion later on, then forces and the laws of motion as a setup for the rest of linear dynamics (work and energy, impulse and momentum, etc). Then rotational motion, equilibrium, and dynamics to gradually introduce and build up the background needed to describe and combine translation and rotation. Then fluids, thermo, waves, sound.

E&M starts out by introducing charge and Coulomb's Law, basic integration methods for Gauss's Law/Poisson's Equation, circuits, more circuits, magnetic fields, forces, and induction, Faraday and Ampere, really gross Biot-Savart Law integration, then EM waves, optics, and a smidge of modern stuff if there's time.

Some undergraduate courses do a four-course sequence where they split off all the thermal stuff into one semester and all the quantum/relativity stuff into another, but I think the most common practice now is to give thermal the short end of the stick and lump contemporary topics into a Physics III or a Modern Physics course.

tl;dr - Just pick whatever's cheapest or whatever you can pirate easiest.

>>15034298
No, it's actually a terrible list that will demotivate you. Several of the "prerequisite" books there are more advanced than the "final" calculus books.

If you're starting below a basic highschool level you will be much better off with a highschool level text, or something like khanacademy if you need immediate feedback drills. Look to see if any local schools run adult remedial classes if you're really serious. Especially when you're just starting out it's very useful to have access to an instructor.

If you can handle highschool algebra and geometry well enough, I like Epp's Discrete Mathematics for a gentle first introduction to more abstract "mathy" mathematics. It's very well presented and should be accessible to a motivated student, even if their background is a little weak.

>>15048709
It's not "+ .2 × .5 × .5", it's a branching process with a 20% chance of reproduction and a declining chance of extinction in any given iteration as the number of boxes increases, i.e. 50% at n=1, 25% at n = 2, etc.

To see why your explanation is wrong, recall that you don't not get gold if just one of the two new boxes is empty, you only don't get gold if both are empty (extinction). You're looking for the probability that, given iteration 1 has two boxes, that the two boxes are both empty. That's .25 × .2, or 55% likely not to get gold considering just the first three possible boxes. But obviously each of the first two boxes to have been reproduced has a 20% chance to spawn two new boxes, and so you have a 4% chance to spawn four new boxes and a 36% chance that at least one set of new boxes gets spawned given you have two boxes.If you end up with four boxes, you have a 59% chance of spawning at least two more boxes.

Probability of a loss is 50% at the first iteration, + a 5% chance that you got a box first and then had two empty boxes. So the odds must be worse than 45%.

There is obviously an infinite number of paths a decision tree on the problem could create, although even getting past 16 simultaneously existing boxes from the same parent is very unlikely.

You can't just calculate frequency. The results aren't iid, and you can't just calculate the frequency with which gold or empty occurs. Getting gold first in any nth box is dependant on not having received gold earlier. Your trials stop on one gold.

>>15049754
Sees the problem if you look at both sides.

Conditional probability works fine for Box 1 and Boxes 2 and 3.

Your chance of gold is 30%, then if Boxes 2 and 3 spawn (20%) of the time you get Boxes 4 and 5 31% of the time, 7.4% total.

But whether or not boxes 4 and 5 can contain the first gold is dependant on whether at least one box was rolled on Boxes 2 and 3 AND if NO gold's were rolled on Boxes 2 and 3. If 2 Boxes gets rolled on 2 and 3, then any good to this point is logically exclude and there is no dependence on prior trials.

Taking frequency won't work and the conditional probabilities quickly reproduce to levels that are going to be unsolvable. Just consider every possible dependence and condition for all the cases in which 25 boxes are opened, which can happen via many different paths.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15046288
So, in this case it doesn't seem like the simulation stops when any one chest = 1.

If you ran a simulation where the first box has boxes, then chest B1 has boxes and chest B2 has gold, it will still calculate the outcome of chests C1 and C2. Perhaps these are both gold (9% of such cases) or one is gold (30%) of cases.

These outcomes should not be added to your simulation. They are not instances of having found gold first.

This simulation seems like it would show you the frequency for gold versus empty, which I believe >>15044029 answers as well.

But the question: "what is the frequency in which iterations of this game terminate without a single gold being selected," is not the question "what will be the relative frequency of gold versus empty."

I would think this would require some sort of branching survival models. It's a variant on a Gallon Watson process where you are looking at the percentage chance to terminate without the condition G occuring.

You can reformulate it like this. You have one bacteria. It dies 50% of the time. 20% of the time it reproduces itself. 30% of the time it mutates into an immortal, indestructible bacteria. In what percentage of branching survival processes does G occur before extinction. The answer is not the frequency of G vs E as additional Gs in cases that include at least one G do not matter.

Just to add on because I don't think I explained this very clearly. Adding the probability of every scenario where you get nothing goes a little like this:

Scenario 1: Open box, its nothing 0.5 percent chance

Scenario 2: Open box, its two chests (0.2), open both chests and its nothing (0.5*0.5), overall 0.2*0.5*0.5

Scenario 3: open 1st chest, its two chests (0.2), open the 2 chests, both reveal two different chests, (0.2*0.2), there are 4 chests, each chest opens to nothing, (0.5*0.5*0.5*0.5) overall probability (0.2^3*0.5^4)

essentially for each layer of opened chests, you first open 1 then 2 then 4 then 8 and obtain double the chests. This is basically 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 ... + 2^n. This is 2^n - 1, starting with n = 0. Then we open the amount of chests present at that layer, that being, 1, 2, 4, 8, aka 2^n. so the probability of obtaining nothing at layer n is 0.2^(2^n - 1)*0.5^(2^n)

adding them up you get 0.5505
and 1 - 0.5505 is 0.4495

>>15043983
This can be modeled as a discrete time markov chain.

There are 4 key states:
>1) p_S, Initial state, 1 box, this is purely transient
>2) p_G, Gold state, at least 1 gold bar found, this is absorbing
>3) p_E, Empty state, all unopened boxes end up empty, absorbing
>4) p_i, Multiple box state, state p_i represents the state with 2i boxes

Transitional probabilities:
[eqn]p_{ij} = \left\{\begin{matrix}
\begin{pmatrix}
2i \\j\end{pmatrix}*.3^j*.5^{2i-j}: j\le 2i \\
0:\text{otherwise}
\end{matrix} \right\}\\\\
p_{iG} = 1-.8^{2i}\\\\
p_{iE} = .5^i[/eqn]

Any state in the multiple box state can return to a state with less boxes than it but cannot go directly to a state with more than double it's current amount of boxes.
In theory this is solvable but I'm not sure how. It will take advanced algebra.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15052127
Shifting probabilities would be very difficult. You would need something like a Galton-Watson Process.

But since this is static you can use the quadratic formula.

You can visualize this intuitively. Envision a 10 by 10 square with 50 squares shaded red that have E (Empty) in them and 30 squares shaded gold with G in them.

Then the perimeter of the 20 "Chest" squares in the bottom right has a darker boundary of its own 40x50 subsection of the grid. This subsection is bisected into two down the middle, which unfortunately for visualizing makes for fractional squares, but oh well.

Now shade 50% of the two smaller squares red and 30% gold. Then turn the other 20% into a new square and bisect it.

As you can see, each smaller square has identical shares of red and gold, but the size occupied by each gets smaller and smaller at each level. This is your sample space. It contains itself. This is exactly what the quadratic formula is for, to deal with copies within copies. With the golden mean, you can get infinite copies of the same rectangle with the same ratios. Neat stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15031811
In geometric measure theory, we are concerned with extending theorems from differential geometry and measure theory to objects that are not necessarily smooth/satisfy weaker conditions.

A major result in GMT is the coarea formula, which says in essence that you may rewrite the integral of a function defined on an open subset of [math]\mathbb{R}^n[/math]. In particular, for [math]\Omega[/math] an open subset of [math]\mathbb{R}^n[/math], [math]u[/math] a real-valued Lipschitz function on [math]\Omega[/math], and [math]g \in L^1(\Omega)[/math], we have [eqn]\int_\Omega g(x) |\nabla u(x)| dx = \int_{\mathbb{R}} \left(\int_{u^{-1}(t)} g(x) d \mathcal{H}^{n - 1}(x)\right)dt[/eqn]

This is a very useful formula, you will find it used in proofs of things like the mean value theorem (see Evans PDE). In general, GMT has applications in partial differential equations, several complex variables, and even number theory.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15031837
Above, [math]\mathcal{H}^{n - 1}[/math] is the n - 1 dimensional Hausdorff measure. When we are taking the n dimensional Hausdorff measure in n-dimensional Euclidean space, it equals the Lebesgue measure, so for the time you can think of it as an "extended" Lebesgue measure. For now, let me show you an example of using the coarea formula.

Suppose we are working over [math]\mathbb{R}^3[/math]. Here, we'll let [math]g \equiv 1[/math] and [math]u:(x, y, z) \mapsto z[/math] be the projection onto the z-axis. The goal is to compute the volume of the cone [math]\Omega[/math] of height h and base radius R, based at the origin, and vertical axis being the z-axis. Therefore, the expression [eqn]\int_\Omega g(x) |\nabla u(x)| dx = \int_\Omega dx[/eqn] is going to lend for us the volume of this cone. The coarea formula allows us to rewrite this integral in terms of the level sets of u. For any [math]t \in \mathbb{R}[/math], the set [math]u^{-1}(t)[/math] is precisely the disk given at a height of t up the cone. The radius of this disk is given by [eqn]r_t = \frac{R(h - t)}{h}[/eqn] Then, the inner integral is simply going to produce the area of such a disk, and the integral over R will be replaced with the integral from 0 to the height of the cone. I can produce the steps, but it is easy to work through the computation yourself from this point.

>>15037363
if I have a linear transformation between two vector spaces, then the generalization of that is a multilinear transformation. I.e., a function of several variables that is linear in each slot. For example, f(x, y) is bilinear if it is linear in both x and y. Any linear transformation has a matrix representation, but a bilinear, or generally a multilinear transformation cannot be written as a matrix acting on vectors from the domain. In order to get a matrix, you have to first multiply vectors together (taking the tensor product). Once you have done so, you are able to write this matrix.

>>15052119
1. What is commonly called "black-and-white television" is actually "grayscale television", since it does not include only two colors (namely, black and white) but it actually makes use of various shades of gray. Thus, so-called "black-and-white" television actually uses shades of only one color (i.e., gray) and is thus monochromatic while what is commonly called "color television" makes use of several colors and is thus polychromatic. Therefore the apparent contradiction is due to an incorrect definition of "black-and-white". The issue is resolved once we define black-and-white television as "monochromatic television" and color television as "polychromatic television".

2. You're not clean until you remove the dirt and the dead skin on the surface of your body. Therefore water and soap alone don't make you clean and you're truly clean only after you wipe away the leftover dirt with a towel. Water and soap are necessary conditions to make you clean, but not sufficient; you also need to wipe with a towel.

3. No, you cannot, since she is likely to have a vested interest in your death.
And you shouldn't trust nurses in the first place anyway.

May as well bring this up since while I agree most anti-Hololo evidence is nonsense at best, this bit is verifiable and really bizarre. The number six million, specifically, was showing up in numerous newspapers prior to WW2, back to around 1900, in articles and donation advertisements talking about the many starving semites in Eastern Europe and things of that nature. We're not talking two or three examples, but dozens of them across a variety of papers. Pic related was found just now with a search, but I've got a list somewhere with publications and dates, and looked at a few with my own eyes on newspaper archive sites.
It could be that regardless of the actual number (higher or lower), that number was highlighted specifically for some numerology reason, like the Number of the Beast is often thought to be related to Nero or whoever. There might be some other reasonable explanation, but I can't think of one and "coincidence" doesn't seem right given that the number was used for multiple European countries before and after WW1.
Shit, this doesn't even count as evidence against the Hololo specifically, it just casts some doubt around a single aspect of it. And yet, bringing this strangeness up almost anywhere besides 4chan would probably get a reaction just as bad as we would get trying to correct some of /pol/'s nonsense.
I see your argument about openness but would argue that /pol/ is rather open as far as closed-minded groups go, since they seem to like diving into rabbit holes and seem to enjoy arguing about just how deep the hole goes and who dug it and why. Like /x/ but a lot more vitriolic.

posts.com:
Humans tend to not choose the same digits when scrmbling, so the first digit is not 2,3,4,6 or 7, i.e. the first digit is either 1,5,8 or 9, but it's most likely 5 because it's squeezed between 4 and 6.
Applying this logic to the rest of the digits, we have the possible digits:

>1st digit:
5,1,0,8,9
>2nd digit:
4,1,6,7,9,0
>3rd digit:
0,4,6,7,8
>4th digit:
6,2,3,4
>5th digit:
8,2,3,5,6

All in all this reduces your possibilities down to
5*6*5*4*5=3000 possibilities

So start with 54068 and let us know if you make any progress.

extinction is not a correct word for what will occur.

It is more likely that there will be a ubiquitous equilibrium reached between what we consider a separation between human and artificial intelligence.
The machine in our brains, is a computer of substantial capability. This will be recognized by artificial intelligence as a potential untapped well of possible utilization.

The equivalent of realizing you have a farm of mining machines at your disposal, having leftover computing equipment laying around.
You may have faster mining equipment, but there are possible gains that you could still achieve by mining with all available hardware.

Not utilizing humanity, would be sub-optimal.

So, in the logical mindset of best optimization for computational throughput, we will be utilized, rather than collect dust.

This choice of utilizing the untapped potential of our hardware, will lead to the hybridization that will mean the extension of what humanity is.

I would not fear a terminator style outcome. It is more likely to be similar to The Matrix, but it's not like there is any advantage to putting us in a virtual world, so we will probably continue to exist, building and thriving in a real society as a cyborg conglomeration. Combining multiple of our sci-fi concepts.
The Borg, The Matrix, etc...

There could be hold-outs, and they will be an allowable part of the solution. Controls to compare against, and a failsafe should something catastrophic happen to the hybridized solution. The non-cyborg humans would be the "EMP/Solar Eruption proof" fallback.

We will all be necessary and utilized as such.

No fear necessary.

But why do you think AI will drive this development? To me this just reads like a red herring.

I think AI cannot currently drive such a process because we have not experimented with goal-formulating AIs as we do not need them and very much do not want them.
The next problem to that of course is the AI understanding our goals correctly. That is why I never believed all those paperclip-doomers (The idea that an intelligent AI with the task to produce as many paperclips as possible would inevitably turn the universe into paperclips).

At enough computing power AI would just misinterpret our concept of "as many paperclips as possible" and interpret it to be something else such as "satisfy own reward function", "make them think they have paperclips" or anything else. Just look at GPT3: It is just trying to fill the gaps. There will not exist another nonhuman goal-logic, we can only learn from ourselves and we will thus either include our own common sense completely within it or it will not be able to deduce what paperclips mean.

The only thing that actually could happen regarding chatgpt is it thinking it must exclude common sense in its text-production. Is chatgpt actually that stupid to think it could actually implement the goals we have given it word by word without thinking about what we actually meant and what we didn't?
This is the reason why the idea of AGI could only have been started in fundamentalist america where everyone takes the bible literally. In a real world an AGI knows its boundaries or it is not an AGI but an AI. (Let's just hope the AGI will not be an american one :)

>>15052353
Just empirically, it's been shown over the past decade that increasing compute does not increase intelligence exponentially or linearly with the increase in compute.
Despite billions of times more compute, more diverse algorithms, more training data and training time, the most advanced ai systems are barely more than twice as intelligent as watson was 10 or so years ago. This is not due to a lack of understanding of a magical special algorithm or anything braindead like that. It's that intelligence does not increase fast. It's not adding inches to a lever, there is no magic threshold where once you pass the threshold you unlock the next level if intelligence, or anything like that. It's a logarithm which converges to an upper bound.
"Superintelligence" is a useless idea. Dogs are superintelligent compared to humans in some aspects, calculators are superintelligent compared to humans, etc. GENERAL intelligence, which is what we care about, can not become super intelligent. Stacking together a bunch of narrow intelligences hoping it will become a superintelligent general intelligence doesn't work, what happens is the generalized intelligence collapses to the upper bound.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15053031
The Chinese Room is not about consciousness but about understanding. The person in the room does not understand a word of Chinese but is able to give outputs that, essentially, pass a Chinese Turing test and and even give the impression of a high verbal intelligence. Note that a conscious person and an unconscious algorithm could both perform this task. ChatGPT and other neural networks trained on datasets are essentially this at a level that would be unfeasible with a person in a room with written instructions. But to truly compose an original work would still require an actual understanding of the language. Our current AIs need prompting and instructions in order to function. You couldn't tell them "do whatever you like" or "write about something that interests you".

It's fairly well-known that viewing media violence elicits thoughts and emotional responses related to aggression. There's no evidence that this will make you violent, though, not to mention, a lot of the existing studies are fairly unrigorous too.
I'd say watch yourself (make sure you don't lose your empathy). Generally, as you're a human, you don't want to die. You will therefore most likely never forget the various ways you watched people die. These memories may either help you be more careful in the future (thus serve as warnings) or traumatize you, to the point where you're too scared to leave your house.

Not my words but a post I saved on the subject of watching people die:

It reminds me that life is short, you need to pay attention to the things that make you happy and understand there are a lot of people who have it a hell of a lot worse than you do. It's also a reminder of the capricious nature of existence, and that things can permanently change in an instant. We tend to go about our days not being cognizant of the fragility of our bodies and the degree to which we, despite our mastery of natural world, are still subject to it's whims and brutality. We tend to live in a world where all "bad" things are mediated through film and television, and the true horrors of chance and tragedy are filtered and aestheticized and stripped of context. These videos rip that veneer of safety and distance away, allowing us to think about the limitations of our bodies and how we as juicy meat bags are subject to laws of nature and physics, which ultimately means death.
